mods.abstract: North view on Market Street (Second Avenue) from Broadway. On the right, the Watkins Block building has signs for businesses Frith & Co., Spurlock-Neal Wholesale, and Herman Bros. Lindauer & Co. hanging on the facade. To the Watkins Block building's direct left, the names of some of the businesses, including C.A. Litterer & Co. at 118, Western Union Telegrams at 120, and McCormick Harvesting Co. at 120, are posted on signs facing the street. Buildings and businesses located on the right side of the Watkins Block include J. J. Martin & Son at 106 and Edward Dickens barbershop at 104. Painted signs at J.J. Martin & Son advertise harnesses, saddles, and collars. On the street's left side, a building has painted advertisements for wholesale clothing, bags, trunks, hosiery, and shirts.

The Watkins Block, located at 108-114 Second Avenue, was built in 1875 by brickmaker Samuel Watkins, a prominent builder in Nashville. The building is a three-story, brick Italianate style building. Paired brackets support the large overhanging cornice. Brick dentil ornamentation runs above the third-story windows. Shouldered metal moldings with keystones accentuate the round windows on the upper floors. The center structure of the block has a dated parapet. Four years after the construction of the building, Samuel Watkins started on plans for the Watkins Institute. Historically, the building had an assortment of different occupiers, such as Herman Bros., Lindauer & Co., the largest wholesale house in 1889, and the laboratories, offices, and warehouses Spurlock Neal Co. Wholesale druggists since the 1890â€™s. In 1897, Spurlock, Neal, & Co. Wholesale Drugs was located at 108 North Market Street , Herman Bros., Lindauer & Co. Wholesale dry goods, notions, books & shoes was located at 110-114 North Market Street, and Frith & Co. seed and grain was located at 114 North Market Street.
